/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I believed that this issue was imported by the http module after it updated to the latest for Py3. There's some changes in the client.py. It could not handle the None header values properly due to a check of _is_illegal_header_value. This fix is a workaround for those None header values which were injected by the keystonemiddleware auth_token module.

If you don't give them an empty string value when they are absent, the keystonemiddleware will inject them with None values, then the http/client.py will raise an exception. Only if they are present, the keystonemiddleware will pass their original values.

distributedcloud/dcorch/api/proxy/apps/p.message: This Issue was caused by these three headers. Their values were None, but http/client.py could not handle None http header values. It raised a "TypeError" exception.
Can you add a comment that these headers would be set by keystonemiddleware with None values if they are not present in the response?
Can we not inspect the incoming environ headers and update them generically?

The keystonemiddleware/auth-token/_request.py generated the None values for these three headers in the _set_auth-headers and _get_system_scope methods. Although its documentation said, only domain scope token needs domain_id and domain_name, it still generated them with None values without checking the scope.
I could not find another place to put this check and conversion in our code. This solution would not impact anything, because it did the replacement only if they were absent or None.
ok, can you update the comment to indicate that validation for illegal headers (e.g. headers with None value) was not applied in python2.7 middleware and is now enabled in python3 middleware?

IMHO.. instead of adding duplicate jobs (with fips enabled)in check/gate which trigger against each patch. We can add these scenarios(duplicate jobs with fips enabled) in periodic integration line and once we are confident that jobs with fips are passing. We can modify the existing scenarios(in check/gate) to be fips enabled instead of adding duplicate jobs.

specs/zed/network-cascade-deletion.rst.message: nit: please remove

nit: please remove it

What about ports owned by nova compute (both up and down VMs)? Please describe this case
The "Remove all ports in that network" covers that. All such ports will be deleted. Today You also can delete port which is attached to VM directly using Neutron API if I'm not mistaken.

I would recommend exploring this option. Once (for an experimental trunk related downstream feature) we did something similar as the sync cascade option here and the results were not good. Many neutron API operations today take easily 0.5-1.0 seconds (or even more) to complete. Unless we implement a really efficient bulk delete (which is hard) it does not take many resources (which are to be deleted because of cascading) to start hitting 30-60-100 second http client timeouts. When that happens the client knows nothing about what happened.

My main problem with this is that it would break promise from https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/#synchronous-versus-asynchronous-plug-in-behavior about "an API client is guaranteed that all subsequent API calls properly reflect the changed logical model."

Not necessarily. The user is generally not interested in when a deletion actually happens as long as it does not fail. A deletion can be a relatively slow operation without annoying the user. Also letting the server to perform it at a pace it sees fit.

For example I can imagine a two phased operation:

1) a quick check if any constraints present in the db would prevent the cascaded delete, reject the delete request synchronously and quickly in the first response, if yes
2) go on with the actual deletion asynchronously, what the user can poll, but I guess many clients would just skip
I rephrased it a bit

Yeah we would break the letter of the docs - which we can easily change. But I don't think this would be breaking the spirit of it.

That part in the docs is about the RESTful object model. Doing a cascaded delete under 'DELETE /v2.0/networks?cascade=true' is significantly different from all pre-existing operations in the API. From REST perspective this is kind of a lie, since the operation is not only on the resource present in the request. We can easily live with this white lie, but still the cascaded delete is orchestration functionality, which *cannot be* transactional, and I believe it is not worth faking a transactional-looking sync facade in front of it.

this is my understanding also, with strong documentation we can make users understand that with "cascase=true" we leave the RESTful DELETE operation.

I like the 2 phased operation in the previous commit (1.)check and fail or go, 2.)go on asynchronously)
We don't have async API calls in the Neutron server. How do you plan to implement them?

You're right, there may be non-trivial details to the implementation. I guess we would need at least to extend the enum of potential network status-es (for example a new DELETING status), or even introduce a deletion_status field (hopefully the first would be enough).

If a cascaded delete gets interrupted for example by neutron-server being shut down or dying, I believe we would not need to implement a persistent task queue, just make sure that a 2nd delete request picks up from where the interrupted left off.

On a high level, I believe it's better to fit the implementation to the desired API behavior than the other way around. On the other hand I did not think the implementation through yet and I'm sure I'm missing important details.

We have see _4 (https://docs.openstack.org/api-ref/network/v2/index.html?expanded=delete-network-detail#synchronous-versus-asynchronous-plug-in-behavior ), that is for ports.
As it is written above though this breaks the current API behaviour, but only if the user calls DELETE /network?cascade=true , so all "legacy" calls are intact.
ok, let's change it to asynchronous API idea

Regardless of the method (1 or 2) implemented, do you have a mechanism to lock any other operation on this network? Some operations, for example port update/deletion, need to be executed in an isolated DB txn. If you are going to execute several DB txn, how are you going to guarantee that other API calls create resources on this network?

common/deploy-steps.j2.message:
So, tripleo_free stops at the end of play in case of failures in any of the nodes[1]. Ansible 'free' does not stop at all on nodes that does not have any failures. 

So, for us start-at-task should always be the first task in a play (in this case before DeployArtifacts as some nodes may fail with DeployArtifacts and others running host_prep_tasks.

Also, there are more issues with other plays like Deploy steps for step1, where the start-at-tasks won't work. Some nodes may fail in common_deploy_steps_tasks_step_1 and others in deploy_steps_tasks_step1.yaml. We need to change all those scenarios too.

    - name: Overcloud common bootstrap tasks for step 1
      block:
        - name: Overcloud common bootstrap tasks for step 1
          delegate_to: localhost
          run_once: true
          debug:
            msg: Use --start-at-task 'Overcloud common bootstrap tasks for step 1' to resume from this task
        - name: "Check if /var/lib/tripleo-config/container-startup-config/step_1 already exists"
          stat:
            path: "/var/lib/tripleo-config/container-startup-config/step_1"
          register: container_startup_configs_json_stat
        - name: Write config data at the start of step 1
          include_tasks: common_deploy_steps_tasks_step_1.yaml
          when:
            - ((deploy_identifier is defined and deploy_identifier != "" and deploy_identifier is not none) or
              not container_startup_configs_json_stat.stat.exists)

    - name: Deploy step tasks for 1
      delegate_to: localhost
      run_once: true
      debug:
        msg: Use --start-at-task 'Deploy step tasks for 1' to resume from this task
    - include_tasks: "ControllerOpenstack/deploy_steps_tasks_step1.yaml"
      when:
        - tripleo_role_name == 'ControllerOpenstack'
        - playbook_dir ~ '/ControllerOpenstack/deploy_steps_tasks_step1.yaml' is exists
    - include_tasks: "Database/deploy_steps_tasks_step1.yaml"


[1] https://github.com/openstack/tripleo-ansible/blob/master/tripleo_ansible/ansible_plugins/strategy/tripleo_free.py#L268

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
since this closes the bug it should also have a release note ideally
as we want to comunicate to operators that they can now foce the node down to bypass the instance state check

we also should update our evaucate docs to call this out.

Added release notes
Updated evacuate docs
Evacuation fails if tast_state is not None
Ack

Evacuate is not possible if the instance has task_state. Added check to verify that if if compute service on host
is forced down, on admin confirmation ignore
vm task state and continue with vm evacutaion.
Ack

I'm probably late in this party but I feel that we are mixing things up by making evac with task state dependent on force_down. Originally Nova has a timeout value to consider a compute as dead and allow evacuation. The force_down API is added to have a way for the admin to ignore such timeout and start evacuation earlier iff the admin ensured that the compute is dead. So force down was never intended to be used as an extra safety check. If was intended to ignore an existing check (the timeout).

Nova so far did not differentiate between the situation where a compute is dead because the service group API timed out, or because the admin forced down the compute. Personally I would like to keep this symmetry.

So I think we should allow evacuating an instance with task state in both case:
* if the compute is timed out
* if the admin is forced down the compute

nova/pci/utils.py.message:
you can also rely on the following (which is more sensible IMO)

taken from: https://www.kernel.org/doc/Documentation/ABI/testing/sysfs-bus-pci


What:		/sys/bus/pci/devices/.../physfn
Date:		March 2009
Contact:	Yu Zhao <yu.zhao@intel.com>
Description:
		This symbolic link appears when a device is a Virtual Function.
		The symbolic link points to the PCI device sysfs entry of the
		Physical Function this device associates with.



What:		/sys/bus/pci/devices/.../virtfnN
Date:		March 2009
Contact:	Yu Zhao <yu.zhao@intel.com>
Description:
		This symbolic link appears when hardware supports the SR-IOV
		capability and the Physical Function driver has enabled it.
		The symbolic link points to the PCI device sysfs entry of the
		Virtual Function whose index is N (0...MaxVFs-1).

you can use is_physical_function() and have one flow right ?
seems duplicate logic.

Understood about the refactoring, thank you!

I feel like nova's definition of a physical function and the OS definition of a physical function is different.
The former also requires active VFs.

I feel like it should have been handled in upper layers (differentiate between PF and PF with active VFs), however this is not really related to your change as the original code did roughly the same :).

I can refactor in a separate change :)

Ultimately I would love to introduce more complex refactorings than extract method. For example sysfs abstraction like in https://stackoverflow.com/questions/4648792/is-there-a-python-module-to-parse-linuxs-sysfs

see comment above,

another way to perform the check:
a PCI function is physical if /sys/bus/pci/devices/<d:b:d.f>/physfn does not exist.

the check if sriov_numvfs >0 means : the PCI function is physical and has VFs enabled on the PF.

if thats the intended logic then it might be worth to add some docstring to this method explaining this. (and in get_function_by_ifname())

There are 2 reasons why this change looks like it looks:

1. Very simple review, basically a variable is replaced

2. Operator can configure SRIOV_NUMVFS using sysfs
As a result the code directly reflects how operator interacts with the OS. I hope such approach would make this easier to read and understand for future developers.

_haproxy_default_tuning_params should contain all the old key/value pairs from haproxy_tuning_params right?
I am not sure if "tune.maxrewrite: 1280" is big enough and also if the bufsize and chksize also needs to get increased.

The problem with the old code was that the tuning parameters could never be extended beyond those that were already defined in the haproxy template. Now you are able to supply any tuning parameters you like (an example is given in defaults/main.yml).

Also the old behaviour was unexpected, just defining haproxy_tuning_params as an empty dict in your vars would have resulted in all of the template defaults being applied anyway.

The new code is not backward compatible as the release note states - any tuning params you want must now be explicitly set.

maxrewrite of 1280 is certainly enough to unblock our CI failures on centos-9 (which led us to find your github issue) - but if this is not enough in your situation then please let us know. Raising a bug at https://bugs.launchpad.net/openstack-ansible is really helpful.

An alternative way to do this is to export PYTHONDONTWRITEBYTECODE=1:

  [testenv]
  setenv =
    ...
    PYTHONDONTWRITEBYTECODE=1

We obviously can't merge this as-is because turns out we *do* call instance.save() under a migration context, so our CI explodes on this patch, but yeah, we need to fix all those cases.

If we're not able to avoid keeping instance.mutated_migration_context(), what if we were to make this more explicit all around? We could make it look like this:

 def mutated_migration_context(self):
     with self.obj_alternate_context(None):
         # other details removed here for brevity
         self.apply_migration_context():
         try:
             yield
         except:
             self.revert_migration_context()
             
That would mean that the instance was basically kneecapped while we're using it with the mutated context. It can't be save()'d nor have anything lazy-loaded into it, etc during that time.

To me that would be cleaner and safer than the flag approach, which feels like it could get out of sync at some point (like obj_clone() doesn't know about it, for example).

That said, I'd really rather remove the mutated_migration_context() entirely if we can eliminate the need for it in the last place.
Sorry, my revert on except isn't the same behavior, which is unintended. Just trying to show the technique of hacking the context out to prevent a save() instead of the flag.

nova/compute/manager.py.message:
testing shows that this is also a problematic place where the ironic virt driver saves the instance while under the mutated migration context.

I think (but I need confirmation from others) in this case what we really want is:
1) apply the migration context
2) call the virt driver.rebuild() to do what its needed including saving the instance
3a) if the driver does not raise any exception then we are done
3b) if the driver raises then we need to revert the migration context in the except block and potentially save the instance again.

Do you agree?
I don't know the answer to this without digging further into the problem, but what you described here seems fine to me if it solves the problem.
This will attempt to use mutated_migration_context(), but we've already applied it right?

nova/objects/instance.py.message: It seems like if we remove the mutation in rebuild_default_impl(), there will only be one more place where we use mutated_migration_context(), in _cleanup_incomplete_migrations(). Wouldn't it be cleaner to just eliminate that as well and remove the problematic context manager altogether? We know it's risky, it has always been fragile, why not just close the door?

nova/virt/ironic/driver.py.message: this save happens under a mutated migration context. We should not do either this save or having a mutated migration context.

That is a good question. 

The libvirt driver calls instance.save() at 5 places. The ironic virt driver does it in 3 places. So the validity of generic contract would need more investigation.

The specific contract for the rebuild itself seems to be backwards. The manager._do_rebuild_instance() expects that the driver.rebuild or if that not exists then the manager._rebuild_default_impl puts the instance into REBUILD_SPAWNING state before returns. 
See https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/850746/3/nova/compute/manager.py#3803 where the expected_task_state is used to express this.

bottom line, while such contract is attracting I don't think we ever had such contract in place and also I don't think we can make it without invalidating the assumptions of the out of tree virt drivers.

Yeah, is there any reason not to just remove this save() and the other related ones? I think there's probably no reason not to just have the contract with the virt driver be "the compute manager will save() the instance after calling driver.rebuild()". Meaning, is that rebuild code called elsewhere which can't rely on that contract?
Oh, but the good news is, out of tree virt drivers have no contract, so we can't possibly break it :)

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
That's not exactly true. If you trace the code in the libvirt driver, it does:

  rollback_live_migration_at_destination()
  self.destroy()
  self.cleanup()
  self._cleanup()
  
  # zero the data on backend pmem device
  vpmems = self._get_vpmems(instance)
  if vpmems:
    self._cleanup_vpmems(vpmems)
    
_get_vpmems() does accept a `prefix` kwarg, so maybe we can just have rollback_live_migration_at_destination() pass down a flag/prefix/something down to self._cleanup() to grab the `new_` prefix to clean up the correct vpmems.

I wonder if similar logs elsewhere, like for volumes, but a quick look didn't turn up anything.

Looking at the code more I decided not to pass down yet another flag via both driver.destroy and driver.cleanup. Instead I can avoid relying on the instance.resources being correct during clenaup. The instance.resources is used to know which vpmem devices needs to be cleaned. But such information is also present in the libvirt domain, without the need to account for any migration context.

thanks for the pointer I did missed that vpmems cleanup. It is sad that we had zero test coverage on that code path. 

I will look at the possibility to pass down a flag...

I absolutely do not think we should do anything like this. It sounds like setting the migration context on the instance just to call the driver method is the first hack, and this compounds that by mangling the instance object to avoid a save, which is a bad idea, IMHO.

It sounds to me like some refactoring of the driver method and/or relationship between it and compute manager is what needs to happen, instead of this hackery.
A couple questions inline, but definitely better than the first alternative, thanks.

nova/compute/manager.py.message: Definitely seems like a big improvement if we can get away from this hacky (and risky) temporary mutation altogether.

nova/objects/instance.py.message: This seems like a totally subversive hack and I don't think we should do anything like this. A random flag that says "don't persist data to the database even when asked"? Really not great... :(
OK, I'm convinced. Changed direction and removed the mutation instead.

Dan Smith can keep me honest here, but I think this is going to be a problem for rolling minor updates.

Imagine the case wherein this patch is backported to wallaby, and someone is doing a update to their wallaby deployment. Because we don't enforce ordering for updates, a compute host gets this patch, but not the conductor.

The compute calls _save() locally, which tries to call the remote _remote_save(), which doesn't exist.
Yeah, you can't change remotable methods without a major version bump. That's why you're changing the hash and not the version, which is also not allowed.

if the conductor is upgraded first then the remote end will have both save and _remote_save so both the old an the new compute can have its remote function exists.

If it make less scary then I can replace the save -> _remote_save redirection with a decorator that does the same thing but keep the save unchanged.
removed the mutation instead. The decorator idea is still useful, thanks, and used in the follow up patch.

> Further, however, as soon as the conductor is upgraded, you've broke save for any of the un-upgraded computes because *they* will no longer be able to save, since the method does not exist.

Ah, didn't think of that. So yeah, no way to make this work without an RCP bump, and a deprecation period, and no way to remove the remotable save() until the next major RPC version.

gibi responded while I was crafting my reply.

Artom's right, and is talking about minor updates, which can be applied in any order, which this would break. Further, however, as soon as the conductor is upgraded, you've broke save for any of the un-upgraded computes because *they* will no longer be able to save, since the method does not exist.

I'm -2 on even the decorator approach because I think this is a bad idea, regardless of the mechanics.

nova/virt/libvirt/driver.py.message: This is still used in one location, so I understand why it's not removed. However, wouldn't it be cleaner to just make _cleanup_vpmems() do the instance->domain->cleanup_vpmem thing all the time and avoid having basically two copies of this? Meaning, is there a reason not to always cleanup by domain?

I know this mirrors the existing behavior, but is it really right to abort the loop here? Seems like this is potentially security-sensitive and we should record the error(s), continue trying to clean up each vpmem, and then raise the first one we hit after doing so, no?

Could we not replace the two Condition()s with a single lock? I'm thinking something similar to what Alexey did in https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/nova/+/845748/3/nova/tests/functional/libvirt/test_live_migration.py

1. Declare self.lock = threading.lock()
2. Acquire it at the beginning of the test.
3. wrapped_rollback_live_migration_at_destination() waits on the lock before calling orig_rollback_live_migration_at_destination().
4. wrapped_drop_move_claim_at_dest() releases the lock after calling orig_drop_move_claim_at_dest.

If I've understood everything correctly, it would create the sequence that we need - rollback_live_migration_at_destination() running after drop_move_claim_at_destination() with a single (and to my mind, easier to read and understand) Lock().

In general a condition can be implemented with a lock (and some state guarded by the lock). You are right as in this test we can use the assumption that the test code runs first before any of the parallel action can happen so the test code can take the lock. I think we need two locks as we need to serialize 3 events:
* drop_move_claim_at_dest
* rollback_live_migration_at_destination
* delete

I changed the conditions to locks and that allowed to remove of the extra flags.

zuul.d/manila-tempest-jobs.yaml.message:
It won't work in job definition, you will need to define a new job with a different name. Zuul allow us to declare the same job multiple times and supports multi-parenting, so in this way, this definition is extending the original one.

Maybe the easiest way is to create a new job for each one that runs on stable/victoria and just set project override:

- job:
    name: manila-tempest-plugin-generic-scenario-stable-victoria
    description: |
      Test the scenario test cases on the generic driver multibackend
      (DHSS=True) with NFS and CIFS
    parent: manila-tempest-plugin-generic-scenario-base
    branches: ^(stable/victoruia).*$
    required-projects: *manila-tempest-required-projects
      - name: openstack/manila-tempest-plugin
        override-checkout: 1.8.0
    vars: &manila_tempest_image_pinned_vars
      devstack_localrc:
        # NOTE(carloss): Pinning manila service image to a Focal version,

If we're in subcloud backoff and someone requests a specific audit for a subcloud that is healthy this will delay it until the next patch audit, potentially 15min.

We spoke separately, but recording the contents for posterity.  It's actually potentially delaying a requested audit by 4 minutes if someone triggers it via trigger_subcloud_audits() or trigger_subcloud_patch_load_audits().

I requested that we check whether the callers of those functions would be impacted by a delay of up to 4 minutes.
Sure

Sorry, after a test and I went through the code again, and found that the subcloud.audit_fail_count is not really very helpful. Even the original code didn't trigger subcloud audits reflecting to the subcloud in service/out of service changes within an audit cycle. Only if the audit fails at the beginning of a audit cycle, it will be retriggered. If the audit cycle time arrives and the audit succeeds, and then the subcloud gets out of service, the audit status would not be changed to out of sync until the next audit cycle. If the subcloud is out of service when the audit cycle time arrives, the audit will be retriggered in 1min due to backoff (+1m, +2m, +4m, +4m). By checking if subcloud.audit_fail_count is zero, the audit can only be triggered 30sec earlier. This is the only difference by adding this check.

Did you mean those "force_XXX_audit" variables to be used for "someone requests a specific audit for a subcloud"? Those values would not be impacted by the backoff. If they are set to True, the audit will be triggered regardless the backoff state.

You can leave it in for now, but it may be something to keep in mind if this becomes too complicated.

distributedcloud/dcmanager/db/sqlalchemy.message: At this point we don't know how long the audit has taken, that's what we're checking in lines 274-277 below.  This routine gets called every time through _periodic_subcloud_audit_loop() which is called every 30 seconds, so it doesn't make sense to set all these values to false since they might just have all been set to true as part of the audit sequence.

In addition, you're setting these to False before _periodic_subcloud_audit_loop() calls db_api.subcloud_audits_get_all_need_audit() to see if they're set to True, so these flags will no longer affect the output of db_api.subcloud_audits_get_all_need_audit()

There's potential risk caused by updating finish_at time in this method. Updating the finish_at time would not stop the previous running processes. If something wrong in the system causing a subcloud still in the middle of audit (for example, retrying RPC calls), after updating the finish_at time, the subcloud would be returned by "db_api.subcloud_audits_get_all_need_audit" again and another audit on this subcloud would be triggered, so there might be multiple audit processes for the same subcloud running at the same time. it could make the system even worse.

To set the flags to false at here is to prevent more and more audit processes on the same subcloud running in parallel under this circumstances. If it's not in backoff state, this could still happen. Besides, this will help db_api.subcloud_audits_get_all_need_audit to return less records in the subsequent processing.

This method called before _periodic_subcloud_audit_loop() with "trigger_audits=True" parameter, so they'll not be set to false at there.

If you think this would not help, I can revert this for sure.

If we set all the request to False, the following        
subcloud_audits = db_api.subcloud_audits_get_all_need_audit(self.context, last_audit_threshold) will never get audits needed
They will get audit in the next round (audit cycle), won't they?

IIUC these host prep tasks are now executed concurrently over multiple roles by tripleo_free. So I'm quite skeptical about the benefit of resuming deployment from host prep tasks for specific roles.

For example if a deployment fails at host prep tasks for a specific Compute node and users resumes deployment from Compute host prep tasks, there might be a situation where Controller host prep tasks were not executed properly in the first run and these are skipped by the 2nd run (in case Controller is defined before Compute in roles_data.yaml).

This is basically telling apt to use eatmydata when building the ISO. It is removed after the build is done because I had the same concerns about possible data loss.

[I think at a minimum we want add the reference to https://salsa.debian.org/dpkg-team/dpkg/-/commit/929a9c4808c79781469987585f78f07df7f1d484 in the commit message.]

[Leaving the comment open for further reviewers to say their opinion.]

I do not have statistics to back this up but an explanation why this happening can be found at: https://salsa.debian.org/dpkg-team/dpkg/-/commit/929a9c4808c79781469987585f78f07df7f1d484

the debian bug that enabled this:

https://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=584254

This is basically enabling eatmydata for installing packages. There shouldnt be any data loss issues with this change because we only enable it during the ISO build. The official Debian docker images enable this option as well:

https://github.com/debuerreotype/debuerreotype/blob/32f390b0eff8eeb01fdec135ddc6eab06850c826/scripts/debuerreotype-minimizing-config#L49

ansible/roles/ovn/tasks/bootstrap.yml.message:
The whole bootstrap.yml is only being called from deploy.yml when we are on an ovn-controller, so I don't think thst this when condition is needed at all.

I also don't understand why the added level of indirection would change anything in how the loop is being evaluated.

The inclusion of this tasks file uses import_tasks, rather than the dynamic include_tasks, so I can see how these may get evaluated.

My preference would be to allow the loop vars to evaluate on non OVN controller hosts. Maybe using the default filter, or something like 'tunnel_interface_address if X else None'.

If we have to use an include_tasks, it should go in deploy.yml.

Agree with Jens on requiring a new bug report or at least some more info on how the previous fix was insufficient.

In nodes that don't have tunnel interface like control nodes, it wants to configure ovn in ovsdb that it's not present in control nodes. Now ansible tries to parse the loop items first after that check the when condition so at first it will parse the `tunnel_interface_address` and because the control node doesn't have the tunnel interface it will fail. I think the solution to include the task on only nodes that have ovn-controller could be the solution. If you have any better solution please let me know.
As I said, this whole playbook should not get executed on those nodes. So if you have failures, please add logs and details in a new bug report, so that we can try to reproduce it.

    @testtools.skipUnless(CONF.identity_feature_enabled.security_compliance,

    def test_user_update_own_password(self):
        """Test updating user's own password"""
        old_pass = self.creds.password
        old_token = self.non_admin_client.token
        new_pass = data_utils.rand_password()

        # if minimum_password_age is >0 means we cannot change the password 2nd time
        # so let's skip the reset password in cleanup.
        if CONF.identity_feature_enabled.minimum_password_age <= 0
            # to change password back. important for use_dynamic_credentials=false
            self.addCleanup(self._restore_password, old_pass, new_pass)

        # user updates own password
        self._update_password(original_password=old_pass, password=new_pass)

        # authorize with old token should lead to IdentityError (404 code)
        self.assertRaises(exceptions.IdentityError,
                          self.non_admin_token.auth,
                          token=old_token)

        # authorize with old password should lead to Unauthorized
        self.assertRaises(exceptions.Unauthorized,
                          self.non_admin_token.auth,
                          user_id=self.user_id,
                          password=old_pass)

creating a new option in tempest.conf will allow a tempest user to configure it based on their need - tempest tests whatever its told, tempest is not supposed to be smart and decide what to test on its own

improving python-tempestconf so that it can set this opt for the user based on the actual abilities of a given cloud, is a different discussion. Feel free to propose a patch for python-tempestconf project - although python-tempestconf is not supposed to read config files either - it discovers available features/abilities of a cloud by querying it - e.g. it lists endpoints based on which it enables/disables services in tempest.conf. If it read config files, it would discover features which were supposed to be deployed or which should be running, however, there is no guarantee that they were deployed or that they are running - therefore it doesn't rely on the config files, just on what it can discover "for real".

we can't have a skip in the middle of a test - once test execution starts it can either pass or fail, if we wanna skip the test, we need to do that before we run the test - otherwise we would practically waste resources as we would skip a test after it created a bunch of resources => that would mean that those resources didn't provide any value (they didn't test anything) as the test was skipped.

We know that the test performs 2 password changes:
1. when we test whether we can update a password
2. when we revert the password to the previous one - we do that because the test user (whom password we're updating) is used in other tests as well (might be even in parallel) and if we didn't revert the password, all other tests using the user would fail as they wouldn't know the new password.

So, maybe we could get rid of that second password change somehow as that's not part of the test. Maybe we could create a new user whom password we would update, a single user who wouldn't be shared with other tests - that way we wouldn't need to revert the password, we would simply remove the user. 2 - read the keystone.conf somehow and create a decorator to skip this test
3 - run this test and catch the exception and then skip or pass the test
4 - delete the test from the tempest test suite

I am fine with any of those. Creating a second user with a password, to me,  does not accomplish anything as the test already has created a new users(current user) to get the the current state.
Benny, This is a keystone option. It is my understanding that there is no way to query the keystone option before the test starts as the decorators can only detect tempest config values.

Yes, they are typically stored in /etc/keystone/keystone.conf file. But those can be changes at anytime. And the change will not take effect until the keystone service is restarted. So potentially the keystone.conf and the keystone service could be out of syn until the next restart.
isn't that kind of the point? the test is supposed to test a user's password change, nothing else, it shouldn't try to trigger any exception

In my mind, catching the exception is a negative test and should only be done when writing a negative test. This test is not a negative test, so really it should not be thrown.  In my opinion, what should happen:

OSP upstream should be include configuration sets based on services (keystone, Galance, Heat ....) defined by customers. For each configuration there should be a list of tests that are run(positive and negative). The test in question should not be included for all configurations with keystone.minimum_passoword_age > 0.

src/config.yaml.message:
Given this is noted as a ratio, but is expressed in percentages, at a minimum, I'd like to add:
The defaults trigger WARNING at 80% of max_connections utilized and CRITICAL at 90%.

The source charm has the following in config.yaml, so the formatting will change as people move from percona-cluster to mysql-innodb-cluster.  I'm not sure if this is good or bad, but may be nice to be consistent with the prior charm, so those changing the charm name in their bundle and not inspecting options may expect the same behavior from their prior changes to this option.

   nrpe-threads-connected:
    type: string
    default: '80,90'
    description: |
      This configuration option represents the warning and critical percentages
      that are used to check the number of threads connected to MySQL.
      The value should be written as a string containing two numbers separated by commas.

I get and agree with your note on consistency. But I'm afraid this time it would be best to be consistent with the tens of checks the nrpe charm itself already has and use the "command options" notation.

Given all the work I've done in the past weeks on this PR (it may seem relatively small, but it was a long journey 😕), I would very much like to at least get a PR started to the percona-cluster charm to mimic some of the ideas I used here (to the extent possible, given percona is a classic charm).

While I understand the idea that our pattern for other charms is to pass the entire string of flags to the check, this particular charm and check are a replacement/upgrade from percona-cluster, and should try to be as compatible as possible without being overburdensome on maintaining legacy compatibility.

While I understand wanting to backport some of this to percona-cluster, I think that we won't want to change the format of the config.yaml variable for the check, unless you write code around accepting the current format while supporting the new format.  Hence, percona-cluster will likely maintain the 80,90 type config.  We should really take the extra few lines of code to make this an equivalent setting unless you envision additional flags for this particular check in the future.

firstly Administrative users does not nessiarly mean a user with admin privalges from an english persecite. you could read this as a user that is responible for

this is correct

i think what the orginal text intended but did not say was that when you suspend the qemu resouces are free on the hyperviors reducing memory and cpu contention but they are not freed in the database so the resouce cannot be reclaimed to schedule new vms.

I think from the end user perspective this is the correct statement. The allocated resources are not freed. From sysadmin perspective we can talk about logical resource allocation (i.e. in DB) and physical resource allocation by the libvirt domain. Suspending a VM in a memory overallocation situation might help reducing the memory pressure on the system as the physical memory allocation of the VM is removed from the hypervisor.
